conclusion: Liquid flows from points A, B, and C to containers D or E through baffles.
Points A, B, and C are likely at different heights or positions.
Baffles are obstacles or dividers that liquid passes through.
Liquid path depends on baffle configuration and positions of A, B, C, D, and E.
Liquid flows downward due to gravity if system is vertical.
Baffles redirect or obstruct flow based on shape and placement.
Liquid follows path of least resistance, preferring paths with lower friction or fewer obstructions.
Points A, B, C are sources of liquid.
Containers D and E are collection points.
If A, B, and C are at the same height, flow might be symmetrical unless influenced by baffles.
Higher points might have more force due to gravity, potentially influencing flow direction.
Baffles can direct flow towards specific containers.
Baffles might block direct paths, forcing liquid to flow around or through specific channels.
